With my limited experience I found the modeling too hard and also easy manipulable towards whatever results I desired. So instead I left a couple of parameters adjustable to tweak them once live. The main adjustable parameter is how much is charged for minting leverage. See here for more details: https://docs.sir.trading/

remembered this got posted here so here's my addition to the subject; 

I found out about another transaction fee that isn't listed here. Kast charges users $0.50 for declined transactions (e.g. You tried to pay $5 with the card but only had $3 in the account so it got declined).

The short explanation is that the valued accrued by the leveragors is computed using the ideal formula assuming leverage is maintain perfectly constant, i.e., the derivative of the payoff curve is constant. The liquidity to pay  these leveragors is taken from the LPers. This relation between leveragors and LPers is maintained while price creeps up until the ratio between the capital for leveragors and LPers is 1/(leverage-1). At this point the capital from LPers it no sufficient enough to sustain the convex gains and the leveragors positions gracefully degrades to a linear payoff curve akin to a margin trade.

Effectively this design means LPers are also long but leverage <1 and as price rumps up, they sell the asset until we reach price upperbound where they are completely converted their holdings to USD (assuming a vault where USD is the reference asset). Similar to impermanent loss in Uniswap. 

So the caveat to no volatility decay is that it is true till we reach the price upper-bound which depends on the amount of liquidity. If liquidity keeps coming online because leveragors keep piling in, this ceiling could raise up over time .

â€no volatility decayâ€ â€” how?

This is a new leverage primitive I have worked for 5 years. It is coded from first principles and __mechanically__ it works very different under the hood to perps, margin trading, etc. I have been in contact with different members of this DAO throughout this period (like @k06a and others) because I wanted to make sure it was as sound as possible.

The goal of SIR is to make it as safe as possible to hold leverage over long periods of time. Opening a position requires paying a one-time fee and that's it; there are no liquidations, no funding fees and no volatility decay (the latter under certain conditions). See the price chart of ETHÂ² for example live now on Ethereum mainnet.

My energy has been poured on creating rock solid smart contracts, but I lack the network or the money to make my project well known unlike VC-backed projects with KOLs in their payroll. My app is now live but liquidity is dire, and me tweeting from my project's sub-1k-followers account on X is not enough.  I don't want to make this message too long, but I would really appreciate if someone could support me/us in this early stage of the protocol (in exchange for tokens for example).
